title: This dad is running Boston to give back to Boston Children’s Hospital
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Nick Gallagher, 38, from Plymouth, will run the 2026 Boston Marathon for Boston Children's Hospital's Miles for Miracles team.
Gallagher's 4-year-old son received expert care at Boston Children's Hospital, inspiring his participation in the marathon.
The marathon supports treatments developed in the last 15 years, benefiting children like Gallagher's son.

title: Her great-grandfather ran the Boston Marathon in 1920. Now she’s doing the same.
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Juliette Barney, 23, from Braintree, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon for the Youth Advocacy Foundation.
Barney's great-grandfather participated in the Boston Marathon in 1920, finishing 16th, inspiring her to run.
The Youth Advocacy Foundation supports youth facing systemic barriers with legal aid and educational advocacy.

title: Should Boston rebuild Madison Park at Roxbury’s P-3 site?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Boston considers rebuilding Madison Park Technical Vocational High School on the vacant 7.7-acre P-3 site in Roxbury.
The original mixed-use project faced cancellation due to declining demand for lab space and economic challenges.
Mayor Wu supports the school proposal, citing economics and high lab space vacancy rates as obstacles to the previous plan.

title: Tom Brady roasts Logan Paul, calls wrestler’s athletic abilities ‘cute’
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Tom Brady and Logan Paul exchange banter ahead of the Fanatics Flag Football Classic in Saudi Arabia.
Brady critiques Paul's athletic skills, comparing him to NFL stars Saquon Barkley and Justin Jefferson.
The Flag Football Classic will include NFL players like Rob Gronkowski and be broadcast on Fox Sports and Tubi.

title: Massachusetts emergency room wait times rank among the longest in the U.S.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts ranks third in the U.S. for longest ER wait times at an average of 189 minutes.
Staff shortages and limited hospital capacity contribute to overcrowded emergency departments in Massachusetts.
Massachusetts saw a rise in 12-hour or longer ER visits from 6.6% in 2020 to 9.9% in 2024.

title: Report: Retired 5x Pro Bowl left-tackle offers to help train Will Campbell
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Retired 5-time Pro Bowl left tackle Terron Armstead offers training to Patriots' Will Campbell in Dallas.
Campbell admitted to poor performance in Super Bowl, with issues noted in technique and power timing by experts.
Armstead believes Campbell's challenges are fixable, suggesting adjustments in technique and increased practice reps.

title: More than 400 readers voted: $240K in-office Boston job or $120K remote?
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: More than 400 readers voted on whether to take a $240K in-office Boston job or a $120K remote job.
56% of respondents chose the $240,000 in-person job, while 40% preferred the $120,000 remote role for flexibility.
Readers preferring the remote role cited time, flexibility, and commuting issues; others valued higher pay and office interaction.

title: City councilor calls for restrictions on e-bikes and mopeds, including ban for food delivery drivers
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Councilor Ed Flynn proposed restricting e-bikes and mopeds in Boston, targeting third-party food delivery drivers in particular.
Flynn's measures would ban high-speed e-bikes from bike lanes and sidewalks and require riders to have licenses and vehicle registration.
DoorDash opposed the proposed ban, claiming it could cut a third of their deliveries and negatively impact the local economy.

title: Video shows corrections officers brawling in elevator at Boston jail
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Three female correctional officers fought in an elevator at Suffolk County House of Correction on Saturday morning.
The altercation started after a cup of coffee was knocked from an officer's hand, leading to a physical confrontation.
The Suffolk County Sheriff's Department is investigating the incident and promises disciplinary action based on investigation results.

title: Asparagus could soon become Massachusetts’ official state vegetable
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Massachusetts legislators propose making asparagus the official state vegetable, highlighting its significance in Western Massachusetts.
State Rep. Homar Gomez and Sen. Jo Comerford filed a bill, initiated by Hadley students, advocating for asparagus.
Asparagus, once central to Hadley's agriculture, still thrives in the state with 175 farms across 215 acres.
